  1. Cover by Jose Luiz Garcia-Lopez.
name: Crisis

description:
Dr. Manhattan sits on Mars using his precognitive powers to determine when the picture he is holding will fall the surface. He spends the next several panels thinking about his past.

He flashes back to when he was 16. He is repairing a pocket watch. His father enters the room and decides that he doesn’t want his son to take up a dying trade, and wants him to going into nuclear science, specifically bombs. He dumps the watch pieces off a fire escape.

He then goes onto for a science company. As he is being shown around, he runs into Janey Slater. The talk for a bit and she buys him a drink. He then flashes to days at the carnival with Janey, making love to her, repairing watches, and the experiment that made him Dr. Manhattan. He got locked into a test vault that separates objects from their intrinsic fields. The door has a safety feature that couldn’t get him out or stop the process. A couple of months later, weird ghost like images start to appear in the laboratories. One day, a full-fledged boy appeared. Jon was now Dr. Manhattan.

Time goes on and the government uses Manhattan as a weapon to crush any adversary they face. He meets different costumes at various times but never really establishes a relationship.

Manhattan tired to go back to his life with Janey but eventually it failed. The stress of his new powers along with his unemotional ways caused him to get with Laurie, the Silk Spectre.

He remembers being with The Comedian in Vietnam, and all the killing and violence that went on there. He remembers the lives he took there.

He then goes to see his friend Adrian Veidt in his Artic establishment. From there he recalls the Keene Act of ’77, and who got to stay masked and who was forced to retire. Rorschach did not retire. The next two pages flash a panel of most of the important moments of his life.

The story returns to the present, with Dr. Manhattan floating above the surface of Mars. From nothing arises a great castle made from his mind. He stands on the balcony of his castle and watches a meteor shower.
name: Watchmaker

description: This issue features a different type of Airboy story: the origin of Airboy’s plane told from the viewpoint of the plane. Issue also has a one-page text feature on “The Flying Fool” and Sky Wolf in “I Don’t Need My Grave – Part 1” in which Sky Wolf helps a friend threatened by drug smugglers.
name: I Am Birdie; I Don't Need My Grave, Part 1

description:
Mr.Monster presents two tales of terror.

Michael, a young boy, is afraid monsters will come in the night. His parents don't believe him, blaming the Mr. Monster comics for Michael's overactive imagination. Until they are confronted by a real monster. Mr. Monster saves the family, after which Michael isn't afraid anymore.

Just as humans are afraid of monsters under their bed, it turns out that monsters are afraid of Mr. Monster under their bed.

Having been uniquely outfitted by Sir Wilford Kingsly for the rescue mission, Luger is hot on the trail of the people who kidnapped Kingsly's daughter. But John also has to deal with his mentally deranged sister, who believes SHE is John Luger.
Condor and Shatterman have an appointment with the Crusaders to apply for membership. Unfortunately, the villainous Crushers have taken over Crusader Citadel before the two new heroes arrive.
name: A Charge of Mayhem!

description:
Contents

This issue contains the Usagi Yojimbo story "A Quiet Meal" by Stan Sakai, Chapter 6 (of 6) of Steven A. Gallacci's "Birthright", and the Jack Bunny story "Archrivals" by Mark Armstrong.

Reprints

"A Quiet Meal" was reprinted in Usagi Yojimbo TPB #1: The Ronin.

Plot of "A Quiet Meal"

Usagi is seeking a quiet meal at a roadside inn. He is disturbed by a party of drunk gamblers. They threaten to attack him, but Usagi calmly displays why this would be a very bad idea. After a moment's thought, the gamblers wait outside for Usagi to finish his quiet meal.
name: Critters #6

deck: The year is 2032. Corruption, prostitution, and cameras are everywhere; from the top of what's left of the American government to the bottom of the sleaziest pit imaginable. When former vid star Reuben Flagg is drafted into the Plexus Rangers, he's sent to Chicago, a cesspool of gang violence, dirty politics and urban warfare. It's enough to crush an ordinary man but Reuben is a survivor and with the help of his new friends, he just might be the man to put it all back together.
description:
Peg Krieger-Blitz has taken over QUSA, Bill feels ostracized and to top it all off a group of assassins are in town with him at the top of their dance card. Reuben gets in the middle of things when he tracks down Bill in an attempt to get him to reconcile with Peg. Everything goes sideways when Bill gets kidnapped by British Royalists intent on restoring the rightful heir to the British Crown. Reuben stows away on the kidnappers' plane, bound for the seat of British power... Oklahoma.

This issue also contains an 8 page backup story: The Producer, by Grant and Breyfogle.
name: Oklahoma U.K. Part 1

description: The Badger fights litterbugs and and rich illegal racers.
name: Beaver Drop
